channel.title: How much value does money really have?
channel.description:
This past weekend my friend and I bought 10 McChickens and 10 McDoubles when we knew we would have been fine with 1 of each. Later I think back on it and evaluate the value of money and how much it really means to us. I did it for the memory and fun.
So, ITT, discuss how much you value cash? Could you go out of your way to buy a homeless person food? Buy something to use for only a day? Make an over-the-top donation to something?
Also, if you've done anything that you could consider a "waste of money", tell about it.
Discuss.

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Marijuana. Worth it.

Read full topic

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

jme:

They spend it on drugs and alcohol.

Not every homeless person fits the stereotype of being either alcoholic or on drugs. I’m pretty sure they’d rather have some somewhat decent food rather than eating out of bins.

Read full topic

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

T3arful:

Homeless people still use money in order to get by in day to day life.

They spend it on drugs and alcohol.

Free food is not hard to come by. I’ve been there, and all you need is a good sikh temple to give out free delicious spicy food every night

item.source: How much value does money really have?

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote="`Lewk_, post:30, topic:330828"]But who would like to sleep in the cold rain, or in the middle of winter, in dirty streets, where you’re respected by no one. You’re day would be picking through trash cans and asking for change, and plus with kids running around doing shit, who knows what they’ll do. I heard that some kids lit a hobo on fire while he was sleeping? Dangerous, uncomfortable, and pointless.[/quote]Who would want to deal with the responsibilities of a leading CEO where everyone’s expectations of you are exponentially greater every day you hold the title. Your day would be consistent desk work and operating around a scheduled life. I heard successful people are assassinated, humiliated globally, and make decisions that disappoint millions of people which in-turn destroys their reputation at that given moment. Dangerous, uncomfortable, and pointless.

Read full topic
item.source: How much value does money really have?

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @P_I_M_P_3_D_Tut `Lewk_
item.description:
@P_I_M_P_3_D_Tut wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:28, topic:330828”][quote author=`Lewk_ link=topic=427201.msg3138105#msg3138105 date=1267237007]

Money is nothing. Yes its good to have, but you really don’t need it.

I’ll make sure to stop by at your box to say hi while you’re washing your hair with rain water.
[/quote]If you think about it, in the lowest point of a hobos life, he has the optimism of the stars at night. And in the lowest point of a successful businessman’s life, he has nothing to show but empty pockets. When you’ve lived without the blindfold of wealth, you are offered opportunities others would never obtain-- good or bad.[/quote]
I partially agree. But who would like to sleep in the cold rain, or in the middle of winter, in dirty streets, where you’re respected by no one. You’re day would be picking through trash cans and asking for change, and plus with kids running around doing shit, who knows what they’ll do. I heard that some kids lit a hobo on fire while he was sleeping? Dangerous, uncomfortable, and pointless.

Read full topic
item.source: How much value does money really have?

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“WowILikeToCode, post:25, topic:330828”][quote author=T3arful link=topic=427201.msg3137884#msg3137884 date=1267219548]

Homeless people manage… Just…

I wouldn’t call living on the streets and having to rely on strangers managing. If they manage so well, why do most of them turn to drink?
[/quote]

Yes, however i sed …Just, meaning they only just manage an di am aware most of them turn to drink or drugs, but if you were living on the street you’d be so depressed you’d do that too.[/quote]You can’t pend that expectation on every bum. I’ve heard stories of bums that have no future intention of lowering themselves to a life filled with drugs or alcohol. I’ve seen a bum family in Chicago that got a living by sitting on the corner. I’ve heard of a bum that saved $250K by begging. I’ve also seen a bum finish his daily round on one corner, take a seat in his BMW and drive to his next corner.

[quote=“T3arful, post:24, topic:330828”]You need money to get by these days.[/quote]When you define “get by”, I’ll give you my input on the matter.

Read full topic

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

WowILikeToCode:

Homeless people manage… Just…

I wouldn’t call living on the streets and having to rely on strangers managing. If they manage so well, why do most of them turn to drink?

krackkid:

you can steal everything

So common respect has to go down the toilet because you deem money to have no value (and in doing so valuing anything that requires money to purchase worthless)?
You need money to get by these days. Homeless people beg for money they don’t choose to live on the streets because ‘money has no value’. Homeless people still use money in order to get by in day to day life.

Read full topic
item.source: How much value does money really have?

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“ollie123, post:22, topic:330828”]The sad truth is, money makes the world go round.[/quote]But, does the world need to go round in order to exist peacefully?

Money was developed in an early age to determine the value of items. I know I wont hit every key point in the matter, but say your a nomad wondering South America. You fish for a living while others farm. You want crops while they want fish. Back then it was based on bartering and trading. But how do you determine how many carrots equals a fish? And what if it’s the middle of winter and you’re unable to grow anything? Upon this crossroad, currency was established along with a universal value of all things. Trading irrelevant items became obsolete due to how different the circumstances for each item was. This is the only true established purpose of money, and without it we would resort back to some form of systematic trade, lowering ourselves to cavemen.

Now, you look at society’s philosophy on the way it’s distributed, how it’s put on a pedestal, favored over all things. We’ve become tied down to material, no doubt. But, without a physical form a value for anything, I don’t believe we’d be as far as we are in society today.

Read full topic
item.source: How much value does money really have?

item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“krackkid, post:19, topic:330828”]life it too short to waste.[/quote]I feel like at least 1/2 of my posts have some quote contained in it, but there are so many that go along with the discussion that I can’t help but post it.

“You say life is to short, although, you forget it’s the longest thing you have.”

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @krackkid Krackkid
item.description:
@krackkid wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:18, topic:330828”][quote author=krackkid link=topic=427201.msg3137681#msg3137681 date=1267200755]
The point is, you don’t need money to live. Money is nice to have so you can get what you want. But to me money has little value.
[/quote]Currency is merely a utility and doesn’t define who you are as a person, but rather what you do.[/quote]
Indeed, I mean people fight over money, when really why don’t you fight over what you want to get with the money? It saves a step of buying the thing, with the money you stole/took…If you got/don’t got money, its best not to waste your life trying to get it, but you should be just having some fun, life it too short to waste.

Read full topic
item.source: How much value does money really have?

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“krackkid, post:17, topic:330828”]The point is, you don’t need money to live. Money is nice to have so you can get what you want. But to me money has little value.[/quote]Currency is merely a utility and doesn’t define who you are as a person, but rather what you do.

edit: What I said stuck a quote I thought I should give from one of my favorite movies.

[quote=“Across the Universe”]Max’s Father: Goddammit, Max! Get serious, for once! What are you going to DO with your life?
Max: Why is it always what will I do? “What will he do”, “What will he do,” “Oh, my god what will he do”, Do, do, do, do, do. Why isn’t the issue here who I am?
Uncle Teddy: Because, Maxwell, what you do defines who you are.
Max: No, Uncle Teddy. Who you are defines what you do. Right Jude?
Jude: … Well, surely it’s not what you do, but the, uh… the way that you do it.[/quote]

Read full topic
item.source: How much value does money really have?

item.title: How much value does money really have?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“Adam, post:13, topic:330828”][quote author=Budda link=topic=427201.msg3137575#msg3137575 date=1267177586]

Its better than us all carrying around gold. Basically every bill you hold is a very small chunk of the countries gold reserve etc. Its all backed up with diamonds, silver, gold, and other gems.

I have over 400$ and i never buy anything over 10$ or else ill feel guilty.

Gems and precious metals have very little to do with money nowadays.
People use to trade in gold pieces, yes, but now a lot of money is in companies, as well as exports and other shit like that.
[/quote]
Lies. A countries wealth is based off of their gold reserve, just as Frell said… It may not matter with money inside that country; however, to foreign countries that money has an exchange rate for a reason.[/quote]Take stock into consideration, as our government is nearly dominated by business.

[quote=“krackkid, post:15, topic:330828”][quote author=T3arful link=topic=427201.msg3137606#msg3137606 date=1267189068]

Money is nothing. Yes its good to have, but you really don’t need it.

OK you try and go through life without money.
[/quote]
Its been done before…homeless people…? also you can steal everything, that does not take money, you don’t NEED money to live.[/quote]Homeless isn’t a bad example, but it isn’t the best either. There’s a large proportion of homeless that are “phonies” and also a large percent that do it for alcohol and other drugs. I have nothing against the use of alcohol and other drugs, but when it becomes their lifestyle I can no longer consider them homeless with good intentions.

The phrase “I need Africa more than Africa needs me” is an incredible example of how much money doesn’t matter.

Short clip explaining the phrase.

If you cba to watch the video, it’s basically stating that we’re being fed negative incite on the African lifestyle. When you think of Africans you commonly portray them as poor, homeless, disease-rid, etc. There is a part of the society that the media doesn’t give us, and that is their enjoyment of life. They’re happy with what they have, no matter the circumstances. We’re so materialistic that we feel the need to pour it into countries deprived of such things, but have we ever took into account that they don’t necessarily need it? Of course, the fact that disease in a moralic point of view isn’t the right way to live, but the enjoyment they have can’t be taken away. In our case, when we take away money, it’s all we have.

Read full topic
item.source: How much value does money really have?
